Introduction Hourly precipitation estimates from GOES, along with the NOAA Stage IV radar rainfall estimates are used in this study to look at the diurnal variations of rainfall over the United States and adjacent oceans. The GOES based rainfall estimates correspond to GOES Multi-Spectral Rainfall Algorithm (GMSRA) and the Operational Hydro-Estimator (HE). The HE is based on a radar-calibrated relationship between 10.7 mm brightness temperature and rainfall rate. GMSRA uses data from all five GOES channels to produce rainfall estimates. The algorithms are more fully described by Kuligoski et al. 2003 (HE) 1, and by Ba and Gruber 2001 (GMSRA)2). The objective of this research paper is to analyze the diurnal variations of rainfall in terms of small spatial scale changes over the United States during August 2003. GOES data provide direct and continuous information on diurnal variation of cloudiness and rainfall.

Monthly Mean Rainfall To put the study into context it is useful to first look at the monthly mean precipitation field. This is shown in Fig 1, 2, 3 for GMSRA, HE, and Stage IV analysis, respectively. Note that while the magnitudes shows some variability they all exhibit main features of the monthly mean precipitation fields; high values of rainfall over the southeast US, Florida peninsula and the Gulf of Mexico, and a precipitation maximum in the Atlantic off the east cost of the US. In the case of the satellite estimates high values in W estern Mexico near the Baja peninsula are observed.

Time Series Maps for GMSRA, HE and Stage IV 9 Figures 4,5, and 6 present monthly total rainfall time series maps at 3 hourly-interval. The time series maps show that the maximum monthly hourly rainfall is observed around 6 PM EST in Florida peninsula, southeast US, around 9 PM EST in Western Mexico near the Baja peninsula, and between 6 and 9 AM EST over the Atlantic off the east coast of the US.

Fig 7 – 116-106W, averaged over 24-29N – includes the Baja Peninsula. A complex terrain consisting of the Gulf of California with high mountains to the east oriented NW- SE. Diurnal maximum at 00-03GMT (16-19 LT) and mostly is at ridge east of Gulf of California suggesting a strong orographic Fig 8 - 90-80W averaged over 24-29N which includes the Gulf of Mexico and Florida Peninsula. Maximum at 21-00GMT ( 15-19 LT) centered between 81-82W, but showing extensions westward. This is a combination of diurnal variability over Florida and Gulf of Mexico. Fig 9- 90-80W, averaged over 30-35N- includes SE United States and nearby Atlantic Ocean. Two distinct times of maximum precipitation; one centered at about 12 GMT (0700LST) between 79 and 75W and the other at about 21-00 GMT (16-19LST) extending from 80-90W, ocean and land respectively

Diurnal Harmonic – Fourier analysis used to calculate diurnal harmonic- shown in Figs 10,11,12. Length of vector shows monthly accumulated precipitation in mm/hr and direction shows phase in LST; 00LT is North, 06, east, etc. Main features represented in all three products. Over SE USA phase is fairly uniform. In Gulf of Mexico and Baja phase is variable and may be due to land/sea breeze and topography. Over Atlantic Ocean large amplitude harmonic is located near average position of Gulf Stream . FIG 13 shows explained variance of first harmonic based on GMSRA. In high rain areas first harmonic accounts for about 50% or more of the variance.

Summary and Concluding Remarks. Satellite estimates of rainfall are capable of describing the diurnal variability of rainfall. Fourier analysis reveals a the large contribution of the first ( 24 hr period) harmonic of the diurnal variability. The phase over the high amplitude land area ( SE USA) was fairly consistent indicating maximum precipitation at about 1800 LST or slightly later. Over the nearby Atlantic ocean the large amplitude diurnal harmonic occurs in the vicinity of the Gulf Stream with a phase between 06 and 12 LST. More variable phase relationships exist over the Gulf of Mexico and western Mexico, a possible reflection of land/sea breeze and topography. In the high rain areas the first harmonic accounts for about 50% or more of the variance. This study was done for one month during the warm season ( August 2003) and should be extended to the include the seasonal variation of the diurnal cycle. Also, the relation of the diurnal variability to the Gulf stream requires further study, particularly the role of both low and high cloud contribution to the rainfall.

Atmospheric motion vectors (AMVs), derived from the current GOES-I/M series of satellites, continue to provide valuable wind information to the Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) and weather forecasting communities. The future instruments being planned for the GOES-R/U series of satellites offer exciting new capabilities that should directly benefit and improve the derivation and quality of the AMVs. These capabilities include: continuous scanning with no loss of imagery due to eclipse or conflicting scanning schedules, higher resolution (spectral, spatial and temporal) imagery, and improved navigation.
Atmospheric motion vectors (AMVs), derived from the current GOES-I/M series of satellites,
continue to provide valuable wind information to the Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) and
weather forecasting communities. The future instruments being planned for the GOES-R/U
series of satellites offer exciting new capabilities that should directly benefit and improve the
derivation and quality of the AMVs. These capabilities include: continuous scanning with no loss
of imagery due to eclipse or conflicting scanning schedules, higher resolution (spectral, spatial
and temporal) imagery, and improved navigation.

Today, areas of active AMV research include the generation, validation, and impact assessment of rapid scan winds derived from high temporal frequency imagery, error characterization and improvement of tracer height assignment, utilization of additional channels (ie, 3.9um) for derivation of AMVs, and improved utilization of AMVs in NWP systems. This research will lay the scientific foundation so that the anticipated improvements in AMVs in the GOES-R era can be realized. This poster will highlight many of these active AMV research topics.

realized. This poster will highlight many of these active AMV research topics.

It has been our experience that current satellite data and products are underused by some NWS forecasters because of the resolution and noise and the training required to fully utilize and understand the data. By exposing forecasters to future satellite quality data, their interest and knowledge increases and consequently their capability to use the new data should also increase.
It has been our experience that current satellite data and
products are underused by some NWS forecasters
because of the resolution and noise and the training
required to fully utilize and understand the data. By
exposing forecasters to future satellite quality data, their
interest and knowledge increases and consequently their
capability to use the new data should also increase.

The NASA SPoRT Center (Huntsville, AL) has worked to provide several NWS offices with real-time MODIS data within AWIPS. The poster presents examples of MODIS data and products within AWIPS and some preliminary assessments on the utility of these products for improving short-term forecasts.

The SDO EUV Variability Experiment (EVE): Research to Operations
The SDO EUV Variability
Experiment (EVE):
Research to Operations

F.G. Eparvier, T.N. Woods, G. Rottman (CU-LASP); A. Jones, D. Judge (USC); J. Lean, J. Mariska, D. McMullin, H. Warren (NRL); G. Berthiaume (MIT-LL); S. Bailey (UA-GI); T.J.
F.G. Eparvier, T.N. Woods, G. Rottman (CU-LASP); A. Jones, D. Judge (USC); J. Lean, J.
Mariska, D. McMullin, H. Warren (NRL); G. Berthiaume (MIT-LL); S. Bailey (UA-GI); T.J.

Fuller-Rowell, R. Viereck (NOAA-SEC); J. Sojka (USU); and W.K. Tobiska (SET) The SDO-EVE science objectives are: (1) Specify the solar EUV irradiance and its variability on time scales from seconds to years; (2) Advance current understanding of how and why the solar EUV irradiance varies; (3) Improve the capability to predict (nowcast and forecast) the EUV irradiance variations; and (4) Understand the response of the geospace environment to solar EUV variability and the impact on human endeavors. This poster will describe the EVE science plans, going beyond accurate and precise irradiance measurements to encompass improvements in models of the sources of solar EUV and the effects on the Earth's atmosphere. EVE has the ultimate goal of improving space weather operations and will provide a transition to the future of space weather monitoring systems.
Fuller-Rowell, R. Viereck (NOAA-SEC); J. Sojka (USU); and W.K. Tobiska (SET)
The SDO-EVE science objectives are: (1) Specify the solar EUV irradiance
and its variability on time scales from seconds to years; (2) Advance
current understanding of how and why the solar EUV irradiance varies; (3)
Improve the capability to predict (nowcast and forecast) the EUV irradiance
variations; and (4) Understand the response of the geospace environment
to solar EUV variability and the impact on human endeavors. This poster
will describe the EVE science plans, going beyond accurate and precise
irradiance measurements to encompass improvements in models of the
sources of solar EUV and the effects on the Earth's atmosphere. EVE has
the ultimate goal of improving space weather operations and will provide a
transition to the future of space weather monitoring systems.
